They did a lot of setups early on that explained away what seemed like implausible moments later in the movie so it worked. Then there was that little Deus Ex Machina moment, but it was so subtle we actually had to go back and watch that portion of the movie again to figure out what exactly happened. There were a couple small details we couldn't quite figure out but I won't go into them so as not to ruin the story. Bottom line was we were surprised by twists and turns and most of them naturally worked. Now, if they could have just gotten by with out the little Machina--though at least the main character acknowledge luck was involved.

A compelling film if you don't mind the usual courtroom thriller tropes--e.g., Why oh why does the defense attorney always have to be exes with the hotty prosecutor? {At least here, she's not the opposing counsel he's facing in the Big Upcoming Trial.} Despite some very unlikely situations, THE LINCOLN LAWYER's twists and turnabouts are better than average, and once this film really gets going, it keeps the attention without much difficulty.

There will be mixed reactions to McGonaughey's performance as Mr. Slick-and-Slimey, Ultra-Mercenary, Hard-Drinking, Wisecracking, Craftily Hackish Defense Counsel Mick Haller. He's about as stock a character as there can be, but then again, he acts just like many real-life trial lawyers actually DO act. I think this film reveals quite well the role that he's ingrained in himself--the lawyer as actor, etc, etc. Many of the supporting characters, particularly the cops, bikers, and bad guys, are effectively portrayed. William Macy (as Haller's P.I.) and Shea Whigham (as Corliss the jailhouse snitch) are especially in-character and add a nice dose of reality here.

In search of more specific things to say about THE LINCOLN LAWYER, I notice that the majority of the other reviewers here basically like it but don't have that many specific observations to make either. It's just a good thriller: That's all.

This is a brilliant feel good feel cool film.  There are few movies I ever want to see twice, some I can't even sit through in entirety but this film is a keeper. I would definitely recommend it and I would definitely enjoy watching it another few times

The strength of this movie is its excellent pacing- it barrels along at a brisk, engaging pace, keeping the viewer interested in what might come next. The legal jargon strikes that sweet spot of being interesting and somewhat complex, without ever going into the mind-numbing realm of the incomprehensible.

Of equal significance is the outstanding performance of Matthew McConaughey. He pours on his charisma at full blast, and even though he's a defense lawyer who makes a living of representing the worst scum in the state of Texas, you can't help but like the guy (even before he begins to question the morals of his life choices).

As for the plot itself, it's decent- not ground breaking by any means, but this is a solid legal thriller. The mystery aspects are presented in a fairly interesting manner, though the characters' motives can be a bit implausible/nonsensical at times. The "Lincoln Lawyer" is "comfort food" for people who want to watch a movie that plays out like a John Grisham novel.

Twists and turns set to some awesome music.  Let's face it, it's really hard not to love Matthew McConaughey.  He's easy on the eyes and ears so he's always easy to watch in a movie. Some parts of the film are predictable but the movie overall is so well done and acted that you've still got to like it.  I don't know why I keep being surprised by how just how good Matthew McConaughey is.  With this and A Time to Kill (also a favorite with me), I'm fairly convinced that Matthew McConaughey would have made for a dangerous trial lawyer.  He's so slick and smooth, but intense and good-looking -- seriously deadly combo.

Did I mention how much I loved the soundtrack? Also, why does Ryan Phillippe seem to play the same character over and over?

Mickey Haller (Matthew McConaughey) is a sharp as a tack lawyer who takes the defense side for criminals and helps to get them off with reduced sentences or no conviction at all.  He is good at his job, really good! He gets called into a case to help get a young rich man off on the charges of assault and battery and he finds out that he and the young man have more in common than he believes and risks his very survival in taking the case....

This is an excellent film with a good plot that twists and turns and makes a good story that is well acted out.  I enjoyed this film so much that I just recently watched it again on the Amazon Instant Video system using my Prime account. I enjoyed watching the slick and fast thinking Haller trick other lawyers, his clients and even the judges to get the results he wanted.  It is a deep movie and I recommend it to you as one worth owning.  I like Matthew McConaughey as an actor and he and the entire cast did a good job playing their roles in this movie.  I rate it 5 stars for the entertainment value.

This was like watching a movie from the days before younger directors ransacked Hollywood with skills suitable for producing duplicate blockbusting cookie cutters with comic book characters, competitively magnified mayhem and predictable CGI gimmicks. I swear, I was watching this movie thinking it had to be made by a seasoned old timer with decades of experience in directing. But I figured anyone with that kind of skill was already dead and buried.  After the closing credits, I searched for Brad Furman to find out who he was and thankfully he's young enough to make many more movies and treat us to a long, distinguished career in film.

This movie was totally entertaining and suspenseful without falsely manipulating the audience with shiny monsters or close-up car crash andrenaline. Instead, the plot's twists unfolded naturally. You knew they were coming but he kept us in the present moment until they popped us in the jaw. On the set, but behind the scenes, the present and past eloped and their oddly quiet offspring became this film's best friend.  A fusion of rap and rhythm and blues were caught on yellowed Kodachrome without predictable nostalgia or sentimentality. The supporting cast of camera work, editing, acting and post production meshed seamlessly in unified support of the story. Matthew McCanaughey about-faced from his sometimes loveable dufus into a man again.  Increasingly beautiful Marissa Tomei softly sparkled as if native to her almost ordinary but notably fresh character dimensions.

For the time being, Brad Furman plans to stick with stories from his life in Philly, but I see him branching out into new territory he doesn't even think he's ready for, making himself into one of Hollywood's top director/producers. He's gritty now, but he'll move into a style he doesn't foresee, at least publicly.  He'll be crafting covertly hypnotic visual and psychological dreamscapes you won't notice you entered until the lights come up and you're unable to stand. He'll write, direct and/or produce movies that, despite their big budgets, will blow us away using only a table fan and an open window.

Brad Furman dons the finesse of a high-class hit man, instinctively savvy enough to never walk it on the street. But as he passes in the lobby we can't mistake a hint of ozone in the draft of expensive cologne following his deceptively casual stroll through the sliding glass panels that open to the kleig lit, sapphire carpet running its full length to the entryway of the Awards in progress.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

RATING: 3.5 out of 5.0

Based on the Michael Connelly novel, 'The Lincoln Lawyer' pulls you in right away with its intriguing title. Will it be about an attorney who's known for his honesty just like our legendary 16th President? Not quite. The Lincoln Lawyer is Mick Haller (Matthew McConaughey), a slick and somewhat sleazy barrister who conducts most of his business inside his aging Lincoln Continental town car. But in a sense, the parallels between Haller and 'Honest Abe' are not completely off base. Like President Lincoln, Haller has an incredible command of the law. And more importantly, he's cultivated the right connections which enables him to call in favors at crucial moments, guaranteeing his success.

Haller is one of those characters that may be a little too cool to be believable. Nonetheless, film audiences will identify with Haller as a man who is never intimidated. Consider how he's not afraid to demand more money from his client, a member of a motorcycle gang who's now in trouble with the law. And when he meets up with the head of the gang to demand payment, he has no trouble asking for an additional $10,000. There's also humor to be found here, when Haller is granted a continuance from the Judge for his biker client, after advising the Court that he needs more time to question a new witness: a "Mr. Green" (Green of course being the additional funds owed to him by the biker gang).

The film's neo-noir narrative, conveys a heady verisimilitude of the California criminal justice system. For example, when Haller meets with a former drug addict client who's now been re-arrested (again for drugs), he advises her that she's going to have to do some jail time (as she's already been through pre-trial rehab). When the addict agrees to give up a confederate, Haller gets her back in pre-trial rehab (an event which later figures prominently in the plot).

We break into the second act when Haller is introduced by a bail bondsman to a new client, Louis Roulet, a young Blueblood from a rich, Beverly Hills family who turns out to be a psychopath and possible serial killer. Roulet (played menacingly well by Ryan Phillippe) has been charged with beating up a prostitute but claims he's been set up by her along with a sleazy associate. Haller soon establishes a link between a former client, Martinez, who was accused of murdering a prostitute, Donna Renteria, in the same way the current victim was assaulted (both had wounds on only one side of their face). When he visits Martinez at San Quentin and shows him a photograph of Roulet, Martinez won't even look at it, as he's bitter at Haller for not believing in his innocence at the time of trial and forcing him to accept a plea bargain which sent him up the river for at least fifteen years (I was not entirely convinced that Martinez wouldn't have entertained Haller's offer to at least listen to what he had to say, in an attempt to "make things right").

Haller conscripts an investigator who he works with, Frank Levin (William H. Macy), a former police officer who looks like an aging hippie, to see if there's a connection between Roulet and the earlier victim. Haller is murdered after leaving a cryptic message on Haller's voice mail, indicating he was on to something. Roulet breaks into Haller's home and admits that he's guilty of murdering Renteria but invokes attorney-client privilege to keep Haller quiet.

Roulet goes beyond the usual serial killer routine (murdering prostitutes), when he threatens to harm Haller's wife Maggie (played by an underutilized Marisa Tomei) and their daughter. While it may have been a stretch to believe that most serial killers such as Roulet would include his own attorney as one of his targets, the way in which Haller figures out how to undermine Roulet without losing the case, is quite ingenious.

Haller calls in Favor #1 from his drug addict client who he got into pre-trial rehab. She fills jail house snitch Corliss in on the fact that Renteria had a sexy snake tattoo on her body that only the killer would have known. The assistant DA puts Corliss on the stand, but Haller discredits him by citing a case in which Corliss's testimony resulted in an innocent man being convicted. Roulet's case is dismissed but he's detained for questioning due to Corliss's testimony about Renteria's special tattoo.

Haller enrages Roulet by implying that he was responsible for setting up Corliss's testimony. Once Roulet is temporarily detained, Haller figures that's enough time to get to Maggie's sister's house (where Maggie and the daughter are hiding) so he can intercept the now out of control Roulet and call in favor #2 from the biker gang honcho. The once calculating but now impulsive Roulet shows up at Maggie's right on schedule and the gang members end up beating him up in broad daylight. Not likely, but again entertaining.

When Haller figures out that Levin had discovered Roulet's parking ticket put him near the scene of Renteria's murder, along with Martinez's possible ID and Corliss's testimony about the spider tattoo, that may be enough to put Roulet away for good.

I wasn't very surprised by Roulet's mother admitting to killing Levin and also shooting Haller, as it was pretty obvious from the get go that the mother-son relationship wasn't very kosher.

'The Lincoln Lawyer' may be nothing more than an extended Law & Order episode, but it's still highly entertaining. I didn't buy all of it, especially the rather easy way in which Haller prevents the killer from doing harm to his family. I also wasn't entirely convinced that the DA really had enough evidence to convict Roulet at a second trial. Nonetheless, 'The Lincoln Lawyer', with its realistic atmosphere and excellent performances, proves to be a notch above many of films in wide release today.

Haven't read the other reviews.  (Spoiler coming.) This entertaining little story commits political correctness as only Hollywood can, making the bad guy as lily white as they can, and it turns out he's a real son of a bitch.

Tomei and McC---y were both good, though Tomei was nearly  a cameo, but not wasted either.  McC----y wasn't really "noir" enough to suit me, and this could probably be re-written in a darker style that would really work.  Nevertheless, I had a smile on my face at the end and didn't have that nagging "how could I have wasted a perfectly good 90 minutes on -that-??" feeling, because it was just good story telling.  Five stars, not for being world shaking, or brilliantly acted, but for being a nice little yarn.

There was a half-twist at the end that didn't quite surprise, much less live up to the twisted ending I thought I saw coming, and the movie never really explained it.  You just don't care when you've been entertained.  Hollywood, for that matter, can't really tell a story that ties the loose ends together any more, if they ever could.  We don't really mind that much, do we?  After all, it's pop fiction.  What do we expect?  We expect entertainment.  Nothing less, but little more.  And this more than met that requirement.

Walking into `The Lincoln Lawyer', I was well aware that the film itself would have to work extra hard to earn my respect.  I don't really care much for courtroom dramas, and I find Matthew McConaughey to be a really dull presence on screen.  I know that everyone swoons over him and talks about his `Southern Charm', but I just don't buy it.  On top of that, I just don't find him to be a convincing actor.  I don't see layers in his work; I merely see a lazy approach to telling the same character over and over.  There has been a lot of talk of the sudden upswing in his career, starting with this particular film and moving right on into his string of successful turns this year.  Much has been made of his Oscar chances for `Magic Mike' and he's getting career best notices for the savage drama `Killer Joe'.  Needless to say, I didn't care much.  I have yet to see any of his films from this year and I wasn't really anticipating them much to tell you the truth.  When I hear the name Matthew McConaughey I don't expect much.

So, last night I settled in to catch up on my DVR recordings and I noticed that I had `The Lincoln Lawyer' on my DVR.  I didn't record it, must have been the wife, but I wasn't really in the mood to think and so I decided to give it a whirl, since I expected it to be `good' at best and hardly something I'd feel compelled to dissect.

I have to learn to stop judging every book by its cover.

As a film, `The Lincoln Lawyer' is riveting and kept me glued throughout.  I was stunned.  The plot twists are engaging, and while the obviousness of the `villain' is a little too on the nose from the start, it becomes an easily forgivable offence since they aren't really interested in keeping his innocence ambiguous for very long.  The progression of the plot is well done and expertly paced by director Brad Furman, who holds onto the tension efficiently.  The final courtroom scene is pulse-racing for sure, and basically exemplifies everything that a courtroom drama should be.  In fact, I loved the fact that I never knew what Mick's next move would be and why he was making it, but when it all fell into place it made perfect sense.

And that brings me to Mick, or should I say, Matthew McConaughey.  Why do I call this a case of Oscar snubbery?  I don't know if I'd personally nominate him, considering that last year was ridiculously strong, but a very solid case can be made for McConaughey being a snub because this role is every bit a perfect one to garner a star their first Oscar nomination.  What McConaughey does here is actually quite remarkable, and I don't say there merely because he took me by surprise or because I expected him to fail.  Any other actor in the role doing what he does would have garnered the same response from me.  I am not one to shy away from eating crow, and that is what I must do here.

Something that I have always accused Matthew of doing is giving us a surface performance, with no actual depth.  I understand that in the beginning of his career he tried the whole `soul searching drama' stuff, and he did do `A Time to Kill' and yet I didn't care much for what he did in that film and so it doesn't count for me.  I've never felt that he has ever gotten under the skin of the character much at all; until now.  As Mick Haller, McConaughey layers so much on this man it's ridiculous.  In fact, the more I think about it the more stunned I am by the scope of his performance.  Mick is suave and under control and possesses that `Southern Charm' and sheer confidence that makes him a firm presence in any room.  That is something that McConaughey should be able to handle in his sleep.  But it is the tiny layers of panic that ride through his face when no one is looking that took me by surprise.  Mick wasn't just a stone, and as this `case' took over his personal life and threatened him in the severest of ways, you saw those cracks.  McConaughey let us in to see the inner turmoil, but then batted an eyelash and firmed up his stance and delivered a `performance' for the rest of the room that read otherwise.  Mick is a showman, and McConaughey mastered that aspect of his persona with ease.  The way he plays his part in the courtroom or the way he betrays his own panic by laying a threat of confidence out on his `client' is compelling and 100% believable.  The anger that floods his motives is also stirring and he sells his biggest moments with such authenticity.  I appreciated that he never overacted here, and there was place for it.  Instead, he displayed an honest depiction of emotional outbursts that stayed true to the man he was portraying.

When all is said and done, Mick Haller may be human, but he is one cool cat.

So, I give this very high marks.  The film is intriguing and engrossing from start to finish.  It has the ability to veer into `television courtroom drama' territory, as do a lot of films in this genre, and yet it pulls back with a glossy treatment and a plot that thickens rather well.  It's more `CSI: Miami' than `Law & Order', but Matthew McConaughey delivers a star performance that puts David Caruso to shame.

Based on a Michael Connelly bestselling novel, "The Lincoln Lawyer" follows the story of Mickey Haller (Matthew McConaughey), the "Lincoln Lawyer" of the title, who defends a wealthy family's son Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe), accused of beating up a prostitute Reggie Campo (Margarita Levieva). As the story unfolds, however, Mickey realizes - maybe too late - that the case is not what it at first appears to be.

Admittedly, the central mystery of the legal thriller is not as engaging as the character McConaughey plays, a criminal defense lawyer whose "office" is the backseat of a Lincoln continental. Clever and witty, Mickey is a capable lawyer, always knows what he is doing, and though he is not infallible (just like any of us), he knows what he should do, having his own code of ethics.

The script is overlong (sometimes it feels like watching a pilot episode for a TV series), but is populated with interesting characters played by the talented cast including Frances Fisher, Bob Gunton, John Leguizamo, William H. Macy, Michael Pea and Marisa Tomei. Josh Lucas also appears as a state prosecutor, who gives a nice contrast to McConaughey's character.

The courtroom drama in the film's second half will keep you interested with some surprises, though you know that this hardly happens in real life. Directed by Brad Furman (his second feature), the well-paced film is also notable for the effective use of on-location shots of Los Angeles. "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a solid and entertaining legal thriller with memorable characters.

Michael Connelly is a great writer. All of his books are excellent and well written. They are filled with interesting plots, characters, and suspense that develop in an appealing and exciting manner. As with most books that are made into films, the films may be very good, as in this case, but the books are generally better because authors are able to tell us much more than the films have time to show and the books are usually filled with more interesting incidences that the films have insufficient time to portray. Yet, as stated, this is a very good film because the acting is consistently very good, and Matthew McConaughey gives an even better performance than he usually gives. The story is well told in the film, and we see how McConaughey discovers that a couple of his cases are not what he thinks they are and we find out that some lawyers and prosecutors are acting improperly.

I have one technical quibble.  When you visit, as a lawyer, a client in the Los Angeles County Jail, you do not get a visit in a private room where you can hug your client.  Most of the time you are talking on a telphone through a glass window and if you are lucky you get a semi-private booth where you talk through a wire screen and all the other inmates and attorneys in the vicinity can hear everything you say.  You never get to touch your client.  The deputies are so freaked out that you might pass drugs or a weapon.  But let's write that off to dramatic license.  This is a good movie and highly recommended.

First of all, I'll be upfront about this movie. I never got the title until I saw the extras. The extras explain that Matthew McConaghey's lawyer character works out of his Lincoln Continental car. Maybe I'm slow on the uptake but if the whole setup was this lawyer found it more convenient to work from his car, then I missed that. Even though there are lots of scenes of him going to and from court to wherever driven by his chauffeur, I just thought the open briefcase, the talking on the cell phone and the meeting up with the Hell's Angels clients on the road were all they were.

In another scene you see McConaghey going through old files in his garage so I just assumed he worked out of his home. Anyway, that's where I'm coming from.

The extras also pointed out by the book's author upon which the movie is based that the action occurs in this one justice area in Van Nuys, California, that houses various buildings such as a holding jail, courthouse and various bail bonds offices. In the movie I never figured that out as when they cut from scenes in each of these places you never really see McConaghey walk from one building to the next.

So in this sense despite a terrific movie that has great characters, tremendous twists and turns, great supporting cast (Marisa Tomei and John Leguizamo are among the "names") a very evil Ryan Philippe, I don't think the director who converted the book to screen if it took the extras (which are all pretty terrific) really was able to give us a sense that much of the courtroom and prisoner-lawyer scenes were all within virtually the same block.

The extras (and sorry to go on about them more than the actual movie but they really are terrific) also had the author Michael Connelly (a former LA Times crime reporter)take us on a drive around the LA of the Lincoln lawyer which was endlessly fascinating and very much Raymond Chandler-esque.

I purchased the book when it was a kindle daily deal special and I am so glad I did... it was the first time I read a book by this author... then i found out the movie was going to be on TV and i was curious to see how close the movie was to the book... well i wasn't dissapointed... the movie was very good.. but of course as usual the book is better... I won't say don't see the movie because it's as close to the book as any movie I've seen. Since purchasing the book "The Lincoln Lawyer"... Legal Ethics 101 would have prevented Mickey Haller from getting past the moment when he learns client A, the kid serial murderer, Louis Roulet (which anyone with half a brain could see coming from their first scene together), really killed the victim client B entered a plea of guilty for, upon Mickey's bad advice, years earlier.  There is no way he could represent client A, ethically, and should have withdrawn from the case. Plus, you cannot represent a client in a way that ultimately causes that client detriment.  And he breached the duty of confidentiality to do it by getting the information to the jailhouse snitch (and ruining the career of the prosecutor in the process).  Not to mention that he committed a crime himself by getting the fake snitch to commit perjury.

Aside from the ethics, the plot, though twisted, was contrived.  Why would Louis Roulet hire him?  Plus, what exactly was the set up?  A parking ticket near where the girl was murdered?  And what else?  Oh, yeah, there was the kind of surprise trick ending that the mother killed the Investigator, Levine, I guess to protect her spoiled rich son, although that relationship never got even a slight probing, probably because we had to probe the oddly untroubled former marriage of Haller and Margaret.  I felt bad for that poor kid who got the job of "acting" asleep as their daughter - in two scenes!  She'll probably go through life subject of mocking that she should have won an Oscar for the Best Sleeping Kid Actor Award.

And, geez, Macghoney was just too cool for school for my tastes.  And Margaret, his ex-wife, forgot her name, and their relationship was just too weird that it stretched my credulity.

Ah, another bad lawyer movie.

You want good lawyer movies, go watch The Verdict (Paul Newman), Anatomy of a Murder (James Stewart), Witness for the Prosecution.

Great to have chosen to add a DVD to my Amazon purchases that provides an evening's solid entertainment at a reasonable price. Interesting to see the central character is played by an actor who shows he can play with surprising depth to his performance.

This is not an accurate reflection of the legal system. What it is though, is an entertaining movie that highlights one man's ethical dilemmas and what he does to overcome them. So do not get this movie because you think you are watching something that reflects the legal system. Rather, just get it for some good acting and a good movie.

This is probably the best acted and best picture that both actors Matthew McConaughey and Ryan Phillippe have ever made.  When the public thinks of them, they mostly think of good looking, alright watchable actors.  In this film I was pleasantly surprised to find that they actually do more than act as pretty boys on a screen, they get into their roles with high calibre intensity.  They don't just act, they disappear into these characters.  I was reminded that they are in fact talented when given the right material to work with and push themselves into.  It certainly doesn't hurt to throw them in the shot with some fantastic supporting players like Marisa Tomei who is always a brilliant performer and William Macy who does an amazing job as a washed up hard working private investigator.  The movie is a crime thriller and a good one with many angles.

Matthew plays a lawyer who more or less works in the backseat of his Lincoln car.  He's got a driver now since he's got a DUI pinned to the vehicle.  Yeah his character has a bit of a drinking problem, but he still manages to get criminals off the legal way.  His world is turned upside down when he's hired by Ryan Phillippe's character to defend him from being accused of murder.  Phillippe stomps his feet that he's innocent, but its not long before Matthew starts to suspect something fishy.  The unraveling to the final finish pulls out some great performances and entertaining storytelling.  Makes for a  fine Saturday night.

The strengths of the film are in the writing and the acting. Both are pitch perfect. Matthew McConaughey plays a defense lawyer who cheerfully takes on guilty clients. In fact he relishes the guilty clients as he knows how to manipulate the system on their behalf and dreads ever having an innocent client as the weight of that responsibility would be unbearable.

One day he is presented with a client accused of rape. The client is a typical spoiled rich kid, but McConaughey begins to suspect he is innocent and has his trusted investigator try and sort out exactly what happened. The journey to the truth is interesting and never over-wrought. Even the violence, when it comes feels organic and truthful. It is violence an actual person would commit in similar circumstances rather than heroic movie violence. The characters experience personal growth but no grand epiphanies with soaring music. Yet the movie is engaging throughout. Truly a balance between drama and realism.

The acting is superb, even the smaller roles are well done and believable. To say more would spoil the plot, but Mcconaughey does have an innocent client; it just isn't the client he thinks it is. A gem and a surprise.
I loved this movie. There were many suprising twists to it. Matthew is wonderful in this movie. He is a great actor and I wish he were onscreen more often.

I found the Lincoln Lawyer to be quite entertaining and relevant legal picture.  Courtroom and legal movies for the most part I find interesting and are some of my favorite films of all time.  I would not put this up against say 'a few good men' but there were many similarities.  A very thick plot with a lot happening throughout so be sure to give yourself the entire 2 hours to watch it so you can understand everything that is going on.  You might get confused if you miss even 5 minutes of it.  Overall, if you are a fan of legal movies be sure to check it out.

*A Brief Note to Readers: If you find this review "not helpful", please take a moment to tell me why in the comment section. Thank you.*

A crime thriller adapted from Michael Connelly's best selling novel of the same name, "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a solid and entertaining film that is easy to follow.  It is rife with noteworthy performances and events that offer its main character a new outlook on himself and the law.

Mick Haller (McConnaughey) is a high-profile defense attorney in LA who is known for his good looks, devil-may-care persona and fetish for Lincoln towncars.  His ex-wife and fellow attorney Maggie (Tomei) is immune to the facade, decrying his sensibilities as a lawyer ("I'm trying like hell to keep scumbags off the street while you're busy putting them right back on it") right along with local law enforcement ("Where does someone like you sleep at night?  With all the scum you represent?").  Haller laughs it off but his good humor is stifled when he offers to defend Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe) against a rape charge. When his client's self-proclaimed innocence doesn't mesh with the facts and things get sinister and dangerous, Haller ends up fighting for his life to render a verdict he doesn't believe in.

Though this movie was enjoyable, it takes one too many liberties for my liking.  First, when Roulet is on the stand, he directly addresses the jury to once again proclaim his innocence while giving them a sob story (this would never fly in a real courtroom).  Then, towards the film's end, Mick calls in a "favor" and exacts some justice of his own.  I just can't see him getting away with this one considering the circumstances: he represents the people who perform said "favor", his victim is able to place him at a specific location at a specific time, and there is property damage and assault involved.  Far-fetched, in my opinion, but I guess at this point the audience is only supposed to care about seeing a scumbag get what he deserves.  And let's not even mention the unlicensed firearm he uses to defend himself during a skirmish.

What viewers can fathom is Mick's dilemma in defending a man whose innocence is either questionable or false, and McConnaughey renders his character's tribulation splendidly.  Though I don't think it equals his performance in "A Time To Kill", it comes fairly close.  Phillippe is passable as the arrogant Roulet.  He doesn't come off as menacing as the character could be - all I saw was a Machiavellian pipsqueak but perhaps this is the interpretation the director wanted. It's a shame that Tomei is relegated to the background; I wanted to see more of her, especially since her character was an attorney.  Most everyone else ranges from good to serviceable.  The only error in casting I see here is William H. Macy - why give a man that talented such a short-lived role?  What a waste.

Though this kind of story has been done before in different ways and possesses a predictable outcome (most movies like this don't let the bad guys get away), "The Lincoln Lawyer" is decent entertainment for someone who wants an exciting plot and a denouement that gives a sense of closure.
This is a fabulous movie.  If you watch it twice you pick up much more information that is easily missed.

Sometimes, a pretty boy actor doesn't get interesting until he's developed a few more wrinkles on his face, gravitas on his mug, suggesting a life having lived. Of late, Matthew McConaughey has been dismissed by naysayers as a good-looking huckster, grinning that toothy grin, flexing those ripped abs. And he hasn't done himself any favors with his recent cinematic outings (GHOSTS OF GIRLFRIENDS PAST, really?). THE LINCOLN LAWYER, adapted from Michael Connelly's novel, should get his critics off his back some. It's a corker of a legal thriller, and McConaughey hasn't been this watchable in years.

McConaughey plays Mick Haller, Los Angeles's slickest criminal defense attorney, the sort of sleazy legal practitioner that Atticus Finch longs to take behind the woodshed. Mick, who works out of the back seat of his classic Lincoln Town Car, has sold out a long time ago. He doesn't give an ef if a guy is guilty or not as long as the money's good. He lists on his rolodex some of L.A.'s shadiest lowlifes. Although, this time out, he's landed a posh client (Ryan Phillippe) accused of assault and attempted murder, except that this uppercrust young gent claims his innocence. But they all say they're innocent, ain't that so? Mick Haller regards this as a slam-dunk case. The rest of us know better. Strap in for a rollercoaster ride of ruses, runarounds, and reversals.

It's a solid supporting cast. I am so glad Marisa Tomei got cast instead of some vapid model-type. Tomei is a real-looking woman and beautiful. She plays Mick Haller's fierce rival in court, a tough prosecutor as well as his ex-wife and the mother of his daughter. When the chips are down, she becomes Mick's most steadfast anchor. William H. Macy again makes lemonade out of lemon with his otherwise-would've-been-blah part of Mick's investigator. John Leguizamo does his usual squirrelly thing as a bail bondsman who tips off Mick to this plum case (but even that's a lie). In just a few short scenes Michael Pea provides one of the film's most sobering moments as he transitions from Mick's weepy panic-struck client to a hardened, dead-eyed convict. Josh Lucas, whom I always regarded as something of a McConaughey look-alike, goes up against McConaughey in court and he's pretty workmanlike, but not bad.

There's enough twisty material here to make you lean into the screen. As Mick unearths deception after deception, he begins to suspect that his rich client may well be guilty (but is he?). One knock against the plot is that it does seem a bit too contrived that one of Mick's old cases happens to tie into this new one. There's a nasty, low-down feel to this story, a scruffy edginess, and it grips you. McConaughey invests a measure of grit and slime into his performance, and I really enjoyed it. Check out his Mick Haller, sly as a serpent, fast-talking, deal-making, working all the angles, scruples gathering dust on the shelf. Except that there may be a twinge of righteousness still left in Mick Haller which might make him turn a corner. Or is that another red herring? THE LINCOLN LAWYER doesn't achieve the heights of THE VERDICT or A FEW GOOD MEN, but it does what it sets out to do. It is a ripping legal thriller and comes at you with attitude. It is hopefully the first in a film franchise. After all, Michael Connelly's written four novels starring our morally grey counselor. And McConaughey's got them wrinkles now. Take advantage of that, yo.

It's been a while since there has been a decent courtroom drama, but happily now that one has come along, it turns out to be worth the wait. Matthew MaConaughy is the titular purveyor of legal expertise, which he does not from an office of leather topped desks and imposing shelves full of legal tomes, but rather from the back seat of his Lincoln. It soon becomes clear that he is quite happy to represent anyone at all, indeed that this may even come from his conscience - his greatest fear being that he might have the responsibility of defending someone who is actually innocent. It's an interesting and satisfyingly explored twist on the usual moral-high-ground style lawyers we usually see in these movies. However his next case defending the rich Ryan Phillippe character, turns out to be challenging both to his sense of what he knows is right, and a challenge to his skills in out-manipulating. All this leads to some satisfying courtroom scenes, and perhaps does not hold too many genuine surprises. Except perhaps for the biggest surprise of the movie - a remarkable return to form for Maconaughy, after years in sub-par rom-coms, his first return to the courtroom since A Time to Kill [Blu-ray] makes you wish he'd never left. He certainly holds the movie together, far outshining the lesser role given to Ryan Phillips. Which is not to say his is the only good performance, surrounded by an assortment of top notch character actors (Marisa Tomei, John Leguizamo, William Macy and others) adding a real sense of reality and grittiness to the movie. I liked it, and I recommend it. It loses a star for a certain level of predictability and a less than charismatic performance from Ryan Phillippe, but still gets a solid 4 stars on the basis of terrific characterization and interesting spin on the courtroom drama formula.
Fantastic movie. Loved it. If you like courtroom drama you'll like this movie. I felt guilty because I only paid .99 cents for this movie.

I wish I could give this 3.5 stars...I feel three stars is a little bit low, as it was enjoyable and I will probably watch it again (I bought it before viewing).  However, I don't think it really warrants 4 stars.  As a fledgling attorney, I wasn't all that happy with the way the justice system is portrayed here (particularly the star attorney).  I know he is meant to be a "hero" as he is lashing out at the bad guy and helping to free the innocent man, but I had a hard time liking him because of his methods.  NOTE: I know this is probably a minority viewpoint, so if you don't think this will bother you, I would recommend it as a good watch.

As as I said to my husband after the first 45 minutes or so "oh so many ethical violations"; whether he thinks he is doing the right thing or not, the main character commits numerous ethical violations at the beginning, and again at the end after he realizes what is really going on - I am tempted to play a game and see how many I can spot the next time I watch it. While this is not a bar to enjoying the movie (as I said I did enjoy the plot), I found it hard to like the main character because of it, and as an attorney I didn't appreciate the portrayal, particularly - and I find myself hoping there are very few attorneys like him.

Furthermore, the story would have (in my opinion) been even more interesting if it had delved into how the legal system ACTUALLY handles such situations; it has happened in real life, and there are cases out there that the author could have utilized.  "Truth is stranger than fiction", and has the benefit of being truth.  While I don't think inaccuracy or "fluffing" of a character necessarily detracts from a movie or book, I think it did so here, at least for me.  The story could have been done equally well (probably better) without such a sleazy main character.

Matthew McConaughey stars as a successful defense attorney...the kind everyone hates.  He defends the scum who deserve to be in prison.  There are exceptions of course.  In this story he is hired to defend a spoiled rich realtor who is accused of a brutal attack on a prostitute.  Well played by Ryan Phillippe, it will take a while to figure him out.  Mickey (McConaughey) eventually does and the courtroom fun begins.  And I do like courtroom drama.  In spite of the twists and turns, the movie really doesn't break new ground.  Well except for the co-star, a 1988 (I think) Lincoln Towncar that Mickey uses as his office.  This is the most prominent use of a Lincoln since "Entourage".  Very entertaining and fun.

Remember the last good movie Matthew McConaughey was in?  You have to reach back a way, but it was Time to Kill, where he played a lawyer whose life gets turned upside down after taking a high profile case in which there are questions of the defendant's actual guilt.  It should come as no surprise then, that his role as Mick Haller - a slick-talking, deal-cutting, lowlife-defending criminal defense lawyer whose life gets turned upside down after taking a nearly identical case (at least outwardly) - produces a crisp, if somewhat unoriginal, movie high on intense legal thrills and unsolved mysteries.  The primary dissimilarity is rather than superb oratory skills used on a sympathetic jury, Haller uses the flaws and loopholes in the legal system to his advantage in an effort to correct wrongs as he sees them.  This does not gain him favor with the prosecuting attorneys who view Haller as bottom-feeding scum.  Secondary to lawyer differences is the client.  Instead of a poor black man it's a rich white man (Ryan Phillipe as Louis Roulet, perfect casting for the entitled WASP).  The two movies are so similar McConaughey even has a hot wife in this one (Marisa Tomei); although, she's not as hot as her film predecessor (Ashley Judd).  Speaking of Judd, this movie is believable, unlike the legal dramas she's been in.  Which is probably why it's so engrossing.

When a man (Roulet) accused of beating a hooker (Hooker), a sleazy bail-bondsman (Leguizamo) gets Haller and his P.I. (Macy) the case.  Once the details begin to get exposed, mystery and truth is revealed.  As the shady deals, criminal informants, and plot twists unravel, The Lincoln Lawyer displays how a superb mystery can be crafted without a ton of extraneous fluff thrown in for no other reason than masturbatory screen-writing.

An all around fine film that has very little room for improvement.  Highly recommended.
This is a very good movie. How he manages to get out of a messy situation is well done. Making people think is a good thing.

This movie starts out showing us that Mcconaughey plays a smooth, tough as nails, street wise defense attorney who is as good as it gets in criminal cases.  Then it rolls into a pretty good story with a high profile case.  Don't be seduced by the flashy trailer and synopses, this movie is no such thing.  It's a very, very bad thriller that hinges on an implausible and faulty notion of the meaning of attorney client privilege.

Shall I explain?  Attorney client privilege only applies to what the client says about the case!  If a client confesses a crime or says he's going to commit one, that is not privileged, in fact it's your ethical duty as an attorney to notify the police if you believe your client is going to commit a crime, has committed one, or is going to otherwise harm himself, and no, you do not get disbarred for doing so.  It's the same thing you do as a psychiatric counselor, and no, your headshrinker wouldn't lose his license either!  The conflict of this "thriller" is that Mcconaughey's client confesses to a past crime in which a former client of Mcconaughey's is in prison for, confesses to breaking in to Mcconaughey's home, to threatening harm on Mcconaughey's family, and to having Mcconaughey's partner killed, and rather than hold its screenwriters to accurate representations of what attorneys do, they tell us that Mcconaughey's going to lose his license if he brings any of this to the police which is indeed his duty to do so.  Huh?  Did the writers actually ask an attorney what attorney client privilege means?  I guess not.

At this point of the film, it just turns to trash and I'm told the novel is the same.  Excuse me for being so critical, but I'm sure you're the same way.  You want your sports movies to accurately represent the sport your watching.  You want racing movies to accurately use car talk.  You want medical movies to plausibly show what doctors do, but why can't we have such high profile crime thrillers like this accurately show an attorney?

Mcconaughey is over all the smooth, brazen, and cool Mcconaughey we like watching, rather than the watered down one he usually is in his Rom Coms, but all that is wasted on bad writing.

Mick Haller is a street-smart lawyer with an ex-wife, a young daughter, and an ego.  His bondsman has just snagged him another case: Louis Roulet, accused of sexual assault and attempted murder.  Roulet professes innocence, and Haller, for once, believes him.  But the case is deeper and murkier than it appears on the surface, and Haller is about to be confronted with something even worse than an innocent client: true evil.

Brad Furman's THE LINCOLN LAWYER hews fairly close to the Michael Connolly source novel for the first two-thirds, which presents some good things (suspense, an interesting lead character) and bad things (major plot holes and contrivances).  Matthew McConaughey is perfect for the role of Haller (apparently, Connolly himself wanted McConaughey for the role); he never truly sinks his teeth in, but he's sufficiently charming, troubled, and devious to keep you entertained.  The film features a great deal of talented actors (Bryan Cranston, John Leguizamo, Marisa Tomei, William H. Macy, Shea Whigham, and Michael Pena) who never truly get their chance to shine, and other mediocre actors (Josh Lucas, Ryan Phillippe, even Trace Adkins for God's sake) who get stuck with two-dimensional characters.

In it's final act, though, THE LINCOLN LAWYER diverges from the novel, and this presents a major problem: the moral ambiguity Connolly built up so effectively is utterly lost.  This doesn't completely ruin the movie--note the three stars--but it puts a damper on things.  Still, fans of the genre won't care.  If you want a slick thriller, with a touch of suspense, a charming lead, and a bit of intrigue, THE LINCOLN LAWYER is right up your (well-lit) alley.

Ain't no love in the heart of city...Can this movie hit a sore spot on the concept of a double cross, which can give hope for a judicial system I want to believe in still. The cast is an attractive one that could have inspired more character flaws and development, which would have catapulted the film into a five star film review. watched this film the other night and was curious about it and it was real slick and polished and it had a old school matlock kinda sorta feel to it.not alot of surprises, but it was well paced and you kinda figured out a few things here and there. it tried to be old school and yet modern and it connected both worlds with a up dated twist. it was a well done film and it could have a life as a tv show.
i loved this movie.  It was not the same old thing.  I love movies with court room drama.  i'm sick to death of the ffff word , explosions, It's nice to watch a movie with some good old dialog.
my wife and I really enjoyed this. we read many reviews, and knew this was for us.  Matthew actually kept his shirt on too.

I found this overall to be just so-so. On the plus side, the story is interesting, a justice system whodunit with a fair number of unexpected twists. Matthew McConaughey plays a hustling defense attorney who at first seems to possess no scruples, but who soon emerges as much more complex. Ryan Phillipe is his rich playboy client, who initially proclaims his innocence, but of course doubt prevails. Marisa Tomei co-stars as McConaughey's ex-wife who is also a prosecutor, and William Macy as his investigator.

The main problem with the movie for me was the writing, particularly the dialogues. Most of the conversations feel very artificial, and rushed - the story is at pains to fit in all the twists I think, and so each scene revolves around the information it is meant to convey, as opposed to being driven by character or realism. In that it felt a bit like an extended Law and Order episode, rather than a high- level feature film. The characters felt thin for the same reason, particularly the Marisa Tomei and William Macy characters - both fine actors who are completely under/mis- used here. Matthew McConaughey and Ryan Phillipe both felt a bit wooden to me, even when they were angry, also probably partly due to the writing.

So story is OK, writing and acting so-so, just a 3-star film for me.

I really enjoyed this movie- great plot and excellent acting. Some of the camera action left a lot to be desired though. One scene looked like an 8 yr old had control of the camera, but other than that bit of distraction it was good. This movie wasn't what I expected after reading the movie description- in fact I almost didn't watch it. A client with a secret, a super clever attorney, and a marijuana-manufacturing biker gang combined with a beautiful detective, cynical rude detective, DA ex-wife and a mother who would do anything for her son makes this movie worth watching.

Good movie... but wanted to not that MM (never got to meet him) donates money to Just Keep Living, a youth program that helps prevent high school suicicde/drugs/self mutilation at my high school in so. california. a good guy, and good to see him doing well.

When he decides to represent a rich and spoiled murder suspect, the story really becomes much more serious and the drama takes off!  Even though I don't like lawyers, I would have The Lincoln Lawyer represent me if I was ever in a jam.  Four stars!

Plenty here to keep wheels of your mind working.  Matt continues to work out, as evidenced by the body shots, which is always a plus for his movies.  Best performance and movie for MMc since A Time To Kill, in my opinion.
I loved this movie so much that I have started reading Michael Connelly books.  They all seem to have a surprise at the end. I thought that the casting was excellent with great performaces by all.

Lincoln Lawyer is a light, entertaining flick with a decent performance by cast.  Five twist? Nah.  Edge of your seat? Nah.  In fact, if you don't have it figured out by the 30 minute mark, stay away from jigsaw puzzles of more than 10 pieces.  But if you want to eat some popcorn and watch a movie, not hurt your brain in the slightest, not worry about a moral, or a point, or not think about a sequel - here you go.  Have fun.

Matthew McConaughey proves he's not just a pretty face in The Lincoln Lawyer. It's difficult to translate books to the silver screen, and this is no exception. Based upon the novel by John Connelly, the movie lacks the heart that enlivened the written version. It does do justice, however, to the character of Mickey Haller, a smart, fast-talking defense attorney who knows all the tricks and doesn't hesitate to play them. Kind of a conman with a conscience, if you can picture that. I wondered about the choice of Mcconaughey to play Mick, but I'm happy to report that he captured the Haller essence. His client, a rich boy accused of assaulting a working girl, will pay very well indeed if exonerated, but Mick senses there's more to these accusations than meets the eye. A mature Marisa Tomei portrays Mickey's ex, and while she handles well the material she's given, the nature of their relationship (still loving each other) does not come through. William H. Macy shines as Haller's investigator, as does Laurence Mason, the chauffeur with a keen mind. Michael Pena, a now-incarcerated former client (you can't win 'em all) makes the most of the few key scenes in which he appears, forwarding the momentum of the plot.  But this is McConaughey's show, and if his performance here is anything to go by, his career should be taking off from here on out. As should director Brad Furman's.

I read several reviews on this site before buying this movie, and I'm really starting to think I need to stop making that the basis for my movie purchasing decisions.  Do other reviewers on here work for the movie studio that released this?
(Spoiler alert)
Let's not even waste our time with the plausibility of this movie... It's just dumb.  The defense lawyer gets a conscience and wants to do the 'right thing' because he discovers his client really is a bad guy?  I mean, duh...  Defense lawyers defend those types of people...

I don't really care about the premise of the film.. The bottom line is it was boring.  The movie was about as well written as a crime drama you'd see on Fox.  It was entertaining enough to sit through once, but I'll never watch it again and the "surprise ending" wasn't all that surprising.

Matthew McConaughey plays a slick L.A. criminal defense attorney in the movie adaptation of Michael Connelly's legal thriller "The Lincoln Lawyer". Many of Sexy Mcconaughey's fans may remember him as a Mississippi lawyer 15 years ago in the movie adaptation of John Grisham's legal thriller "A Time to Kill". Those fans will be pleased to know that the guy still looks great arguing in a courtroom!!! This time, Sexy McConaughey is Mick Haller, who's familiar to fans of Connelly's best-selling detective novels as the half brother of the LAPD's Harry Bosch. Haller's an unorthodox smoothie: His "Legal Office" is the backseat of his chauffeured Lincoln Continental(hence the movie title "The Lincoln Lawyer").  Sexy McConaughey's newest client, is Louis Roulet(played by Ryan Phillippe).  Louis Roulet is the son of a rich family, and he's been charged with attempted rape and murder. He swears innocence, but he may or may not be guilty...  And his case bumps up against that of another former Haller client already wrongly convicted.  When Sexy McConaughey uncovers a deep, dark secret of his client Louis Roulet(Ryan Phillippe)the whole thing gets Haller's morals whirling in a way that makes you hugely admire him.  In the end, I will say justice is truly served to Ryan Phillipe's character Louis Roulet as it is deserved!!!  To some this may strike a sensitive nerve...  In my opinion: This movie is by far one of Matthew McConaughey's best, alongside John Grisham's "A Time To Kill"!!!  I strongly recommend people to buy or rent this movie:-)
I saw this movie when it came out and wanted the DVD for my collection.  I then read the books-and all the Mick Haller books in the series-hope they make some more movies as it was a great movie!

Ryan Philippe has a habit of playing opposite more charismatic male stars,here against Mathew McConaughey,in Breach it was as understudy to a mole(Chris Cooper) in the FBI.In both films he ostensibly tries to outsmart andmanipulate more experienced men. For Mick Haller (McConaughey),a Los Angeles criminal defence lawyer,who operates out of the back of his Lincoln Towncar,having spent his life defending petty gutter-variety criminals,unexpectedly lands the chance of a lifetime,defending a rich kid realtor,who is accused of attempted rape and murder. Part of the conflict in this film is that Mick, being bound by attorney-client confidentiality rules, can't go to the police or the DA. Roulet(Philippe) broke into his house, threatened his family, stole his gun (of course, that isn't proven, but circumstantial is strong), and his friend/investigator is murdered and he is being framed for it... and still, Mick has no options other than to keep quiet? The whole point of the film is the way Haller dealt with the problem. He outplayed Roulet. It wasn't very realistic but it was entertaining! You also have the fact that his current case was connected to another one of his client's cases. Not sure how that would complicate things but he also has a responsibility to that client. His current client actually confessed to a murder involving that client:the sight of Michael Peña, as one of Mick's old clients,going from freaked-out innocent to stone-cold lifer in a few short scenes.

Ms. Tomei plays a character and not just the love interest. She isn't the star, of course, but without her and the other exceptionally well-cast supporting players, Mr. McConaughey would have a tougher time making you believe that he was to the sleaze born. After his breakthrough in A Time To Kill, either he or his management team fell into the familiar Hollywood trap of following the money rather than following the talent. Here, he infuses life into a wonderfully seedy character, a lived in quality. Mick's confidence about his place in the social food chain is upended by a building sense of doubt and guilt, culminating in telling moment when he says, "There's no client as scary as an innocent man.". Mick's descent into self-questioning limbo ends up tainting the lives of his straggly haired investigator (William H. Macy) and his district attorney ex-wife (Marisa Tomei), the few fledgling branches making up his hollow family tree. and Furman can't help but drench the film in unnecessary lens flares, split screens, and jump cuts. All the twists and turns add up to little more than an anti-climactic showdown and a simplistic moral awakening,with the cheasy ending of sucking it to a repeat client next time.
Movie was very well done. Acting was great and plot and themes held you in suspense throughout. Was sorry when I missed this when it first came out. Would definitely recommend.

Have you ever watched a movie thinking before hand it would be a good movie only to discover that it was just so so once it finished? A movie that just leaves you feeling a bit bland, as if had you not watched it you wouldn't notice it but that you thought was entertaining enough anyway? Such is the case with THE LINCOLN LAWYER.

Based on the best seller by Michael Connelly it tells the tale of slick lawyer Mick Haller (Matthew McConaughey), a stereotypical lawyer who will do most anything to get his client off be he guilty or not. Mick is also likely to take his client for as much as he can get while the getting is good. Not the most loveable character you'll find in a movie.

Things get odd when Mick takes on a case for bail bondsmen/friend named Val Valenzuela (John Leguizamo). He has a client in need of an attorney, a young and wealthy guy named Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillipe) accused of attempting to rape and beat a young woman. Roulet claims innocence from the start and Mick is willing to take him at his word. Refusing money from his mother to differentiate the client from the witness base, Mick sets out to discover all he can about the case and all involved.

Using his best friend and investigator Frank Levin (William H. Macy), he sets out building an alibi for his client. But when he has Frank look into something different, Frank ends up dead and the most likely suspect in Mick's eye is Roulet. The problem is being his attorney Roulet is protected by the lawyer/client privilege. And when ties to a case that didn't set well with Mick years ago start to form, he begins to wonder just who this young man really is.

Along the way we meet an assortment of characters to round out the film. Marisa Tomei stars as Maggie McPherson, Mick's ex-wife who works in the D.A.'s office. There are several policemen who don't care for Mick's way of doing things, especially helping criminals evade justice headed by Bryan Cranston. And then there's Earl (Laurence Mason), Mick's chauffer, the man who drives the Lincoln town car that connects to the movie's title. Mick doesn't use an office you see, he spends most of his time in his car.

The mystery involved doesn't offer an incredibly difficult plot to follow nor puzzle to solve. Who did what to whom becomes pretty evident early on. The best part of the film deals with Mick's trying to find a way to not break the law by turning in his client and at the same time finding a way to get him convicted of the crime.

The performances here are for the most part pretty standard. There is no break out performance to be seen but everyone does a fine job. The cinematography is well done with a few hand held shots that aren't so obnoxious as to get in the way. The direction feels more by the book than anything. As I said, this movie offers a decent mystery but for the most part feels sort of bland. Still, when it comes to a rental its better than a number of movies out there and you just might enjoy it.
Very good film that has an interesting ending. Good acting, flow and drama that holds your attention throughout the movie!
What a great movie. Mathew was OUTSTANDING and should work in more movies like this. He is truly a great actor
This is very good movie to sit at home and enjoy. No extreme violence like so many movies seem to have anymore. I would recommend this one.

The Lincoln Lawyer is a faithful adaptation of the Michael Connelly novel.  Great story and terrific acting.  This was the role that Matthew McConaughey was meant to play.  Hope there is a series of Mickey Haller films.

I really enjoyed this movie, so much that I saw it again the next day. The film did a good job of showing the daily hustle of life as a criminal defense attorney and the bit players that all profit off of the cases. Terrific acting, cracking good script, realistic dialogue, and a good suspenseful story.  The directors pacing and visual look of the film kept my attention throughout the movie.  I can't say much more as it is really easy to ruin this movie by revealing the details.

It was everything i expexted it to be!  I would recomend this to anyone who like theses kind of flicks! Awesome movie!

Matthew McConaughey (Mickey Haller) stars as a defense attorney, representing low-life clients for murder, drugs, assault, prostitution, etc. He thinks he's hit the jackpot with a rich new client, but then finds out he's been ensnared - the client actually is a vicious killer who asked for Haller. The rationale for picking Haller is too complicated to easily explain, as well as highly improbable. Regardless, Haller ends up as a suspect in the murder of his own investigator (actually done by his client's mother). To escape the trap, Haller engineers a complex double-cross that's even more complex and improbable.

Yes, I know, everybody, everybody including Richard III, I think, who uttered some variation of that idea in William Shakespeare's play of the same name, hates lawyers. Hates them until old justice time comes along and everyone, including this writer, hopes to high heaven that their lawyer is up to the task of representing them zealously, and in some desperate cases more than zealously. And that combination of sentiments, that hate/love thing, is what drives this film which according to my usually reliable sources follows the Michael Connelly novel pretty closely.

Needless to say, except for the thugs, pimps, dope dealers, hellish motorcycle angels, bail bondmen, public servant grifters and grafters and a bewitching lawyer ex-wife (played by Marissa Tormei) nobody, no viewer anyway, is suppose to like the Lincoln lawyer at the outset. (Named the Lincoln lawyer, by the way, not for his ethical resemblance to Father Abraham but because he rides around in a chauffeur-driven Lincoln.) His wheeling and dealing just this side of the law is what makes him the darling of that rogue's gallery of characters listed above (except, of course, the fetching ex-wife, and maybe her a little too) and the bane of the District Attorney's Office and the Los Angeles Police Department establishment.

That deft and ruthless maneuvering is what also draws him to the attention of a vicious killer of women, women of the night to use a quaint phrase, and a surefire way to commit the "perfect murder" and like so many before him said murderer thought he was scot-free as is the usual case once the Lincoln lawyer was on the case. But see, said Lincoln lawyer "got religion" along the way after he and those around him were slated to take the fall if that vicious killer (a mommy's boy to boot) got tripped up.

So you know damn well pretty early on that our trusty Lincoln lawyer is not taking the fall and, moreover, is going to see that an actual piece of real justice occurs in the process by the freeing a framed man who was sitting in stir through his negligence (and disbelief in innocence) by seeing that that vicious killer gets his jolt up at Q. Therefore you see we had it all wrong. There is some rough justice in the world. And one had better not kill off all those lawyers if there is going to be even that amount. The twists and turns getting there, although fairly well-worn by now in movie-dom, are what make this film one to see.

I don't usually like legal drama/thrillers, I find them very boring.  But I really liked Matthew McConaughey is an actor I really like, so I checked it out, and I am really glad I did!

***SPOILERS***

There were so many twists and turns and surprises in this thing that I was constantly on my toes.  The ending really surpised the heck outta me.  The way the family tried to pin the murder of the main character's friend on him by using his own gun was awesome!

Not to mention the surprise about how psycho the mother of the killer was really surprised me and I didn't see it coming!

***END SPOILERS***

You gotta check this one out!

Matthew McConaughey is a lawyer who likes to win and does not seem to care if his clients are guilty or not as long as they pay him his ridiculously high fees.  The beginning of the movie is a little confusing as he is trying to handle few cases at a time.

In the rest of the movie he is dealing with one of his clients, accused of killing a prostitude.  His client claims to be innocent. Never been a fan of Matthew Mc., but this was a very good movie, and he was great in it. He needs to ditch the stupid rom-coms and focus more on films like this. An A-list, stellar supporting cast bolsters and raises this standard potboiler to a tense, exciting legal drama. Not quite as good as "Michael Clayton", but similar in tone and style.

Michael Connelly's THE LINCOLN LAWYER is given a fitting screen translation and much of the credit goes to Matthew McConaughey.  In his best performance in years, Matthew's spirited personification of ace defender Mickey is the foundation of a labrynthine plot full of twists and turns, shady low-life and unexpected heroes.  The familiar LA background pulsates in new ways, achieving an almost surreal quality.  The supporting cast is superb:  Marisa Tomei as Mickey's ex is sultry but maternal too; William H. Macy shines as Mickey's friend and PI; Ryan Phillippe as the smarmy Louis Roulet; Michael Pena as the wrongly convicted murderer; John Leguizamo as the treacherous bail bondsman; Frances Fisher as Roulet's cool mama; Shea Wigham, the snitch; Bryan Cranston and Michaela Conlin's detectives and Josh Lucas' self-important prosecutor.  One of this year's strongest ensemble casts.  LINCOLN LAWYER moves well, holding your interest right to the last scene.  Ooops...forgot country singer Trace Adkins marvelous bit as a heavy-duty biker.  Fans of courtroom mysteries should love this movie!

As you've no doubt worked out from the slew of 4 to 5 star reviews this film has received - Brad Furman's "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a superlative legal thriller very much in the vein of twisting John Grisham screen adaptations like "The Client" and "A Time To Kill".

Adapted from Michael Connelly's book, the brilliant screenplay is written by John Romano - and it gets its hooks into you early and doesn't let go. It also helps that the entire cast is top notch - Francis Fisher plays the ruthlessly determined mum (of the accused), Bob Gunton (of The Shawshank Redemption) plays the defendant's family lawyer and employee of mum - a man who is all too willing to bend a few rules for his rich clients. Marisa Tomei plays Matt's long-suffering ex-wife and a prosecution lawyer in her own rite, William H. Macy plays Frank - Matt's equally long-suffering private detective partner and best friend. Josh Lucas plays the earnest but nave prosecuting lawyer, Laurence Mason plays Earl - Matt's savvy chauffeur (he drives The Lincoln) while both John Leguizamo and Michael Pena are exceptional as Latino hustlers and hoods.

But the film belongs to the two principal leads - Ryan Phillippe brilliantly portraying the accused - a convincing weeper on the stand who may indeed be innocent - or may be a an artic-cold slasher monster who needs to be put down like a rabid dog and not just put away. Add to this a central performance from the all-too-often underrated Matthew McConaughey shining like a diamond throughout (a sleazy lawyer forced to face up to his questionable legal tactics and outcomes) - and the whole thing feels like a really well-made movie - because that's exactly what it is (dialogue above).

The BLU RAY print is immaculate throughout and accentuates the gritty sweatiness of so many scenes.

It's not all genius of course, but "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a hugely enjoyable watch - when such things seem to be in short supply these days.

Put it high on your 'must watch' rental list...

There's not much point in a describing the film since there's plenty of reviews here, so I'll just say I found the film seriously over rated.

Most of the actors mumbled there lines so much that we had to stop and go back and see if we could figure out what they were saying, and most of the time, we couldn't.  William Macy was a great support for McConaughey but once gone the film fell flat. With few exceptions, there was a consistent lack of emotional connection, even Marisa Tomei, whose always good seemed flat. The story might have been interesting in another, more accomplished, director's hands.  Too bad.  Much to do about nothing.

Excellent courtroom thriller with a gritty Los Angeles setting.  The movie was based on Michael Connelly's novel of the same name.  Several plot elements were different from the book most notably two major ones but overall it was true to the book.  The film makers can be forgiven for the changes in my opinion because so any of us love Connelly's books and devour them as soon as they come out.  They had to throw in some surprises for us readers.

I'm not a Matthew McConaughey fan maybe because I've seen him in too many vapid romance comedies with Goldie Hawn's mini me Kate Hudson and other actresses.  I also love Marisa Tomei but thought she seemed too old to play Mick Haller's ex-wife.  I take it all back.  McConaughey and Tomei were perfect as were the cast of older character actors who almost stole many scenes.  In William Macy's case he DID steal the scene(s).  Country singer Trace Adkins is a delight as the bad boy leader of the local Hell's Angel group.

I was so disappointed with the mangling of Connelly's "Bloodwork" that I almost gave Lincoln Lawyer a pass.  Don't.

Nothing sophisticated abut this court room thriller. Matthew McConaughey as Mickey Haller is the protagonist Lawyer going about business from the back seat of his Lincoln. The cool number plate "NTGUILTY" even draws attention from the bikies. The movie is a romp and really does not require being taken seriously. Just a fun movie set in LA with the feel of a tv pilot. However, what does set the movie apart from your average tv night is the stellar cast not only the lead but support from Marisa Tomei as the ex Margaret McPherson and William H. Macy as the shoe investigator Frank Levin. if you have a rainy weekend and require to kill time, this is the ideal movie with the odd twist and turn. Don't take popcorn and expect a smooth ride through some parts of LA which have you wondering "where is that ?"

What a breath of fresh air on this world of re-done, re-vamped, and re-branded films!! It is deep, interesting, and entertaining.

I thought this movie was thoughtful, well-written, well-acted, and overall VERY good!

I'd highly recommend this piece as a great way to spend a couple of hours.

I am not completely in love with this movie but it was a perfectly fine way to spend a couple of hours, and to my mind the casting was darn near perfect.

This may be M. McConaughey's finest acting performance but he operates in a pretty narrow range.  He is great at playing charming sleazeballs, and he plays this one to the hilt.  Marisa Tomei is great at playing luminous but damaged women.  Ryan Philippe is the best of the angel-faced manipulators.  Nice to see Frances Fisher in a small but pivotal role - she is a great aristocratic beauty.  And William H. Macy can play anything, so his part was a particular delight for me.

The story moves along at a good pace.  The milieu is meticulously crafted and feels very authentic.  I think this is a really good summer movie.

this is an awesome movie. one of mcconaughey's best films yet. this movie is based on the best seller by michael connelly. i have not read the book yet but after seeing this movie i will. mcconaughey's performance was superb. this movie is truley delightful. if you have not seen this movie then i recommend you do

I watched this last weekend. It was interesting all the way through, no lags, and even though it's not an action movie you could feel the excitement in it. A few good chuckles. Matthew is becoming quite a "mature" actor and it shows in this movie.
The combo set, DVD, Blu-Ray and Digital is a great idea. Getting 3 movies for one price was pretty decent. I have a Blu-Ray but most do not. I can let friends watch the DVD and even offer a free download to the techies.

How about a lawyer that works out of his car? And this car travels thruout the movie and there is never a car chase. Right there is the unexpected. I think Matthew McConaughey and Marisa Tomei are perfectly cast and they do an excellent job. I read the book ages ago & liked the book as well as the movie. It is great to see a movie that keeps your interest all the way thru it, there is no sci-fi, horror, nor overt sex....there is plenty of violence tho. All in all, this movie is very good entertainment, it kept my interest and that is why it is 4 stars.

I RECOMMEND THIS MOVIE.

In a nutshell, "The Lincoln Lawyer" story is: A slick lawyer skilled at getting small time perps out of trouble lands a high paying gig and, possibly for the first time, a potentially innocent client; things get interesting when he must figure out which of his clients is guilty, and who - the guy already serving time, or the guy who is likely to serve time - really is the criminal, and how to keep or get the other one out of prison.

It's the sort of story with a lot of potential, and this film doesn't let down. Matthew McConaughey (the slick lawyer) is at ease in the role, and transitions from easy-going and slick to worried and revengeful when the time is right. The rest of the cast is likewise excellent in their roles. The story is clever and intriguing, and progresses at an ideal pace - not too fast to lose you, but not so slow that you're bored.

5/5 stars, for a fun, interesting legal thriller

To me what made this stand out was the story, written by someone who knew or had heard of the ins and outs and tricks of the so-called justice system. This isn't the first movie in which Matthew plays a lawyer, and there's something about him that makes him especially fitting for the part. Ryan P. has filled out a bit since I last saw him in Crash, and he seems perfect for the pretty rich boy role he was cast into. *spoiler at asterisk

Still, the plot was the main feature here. It seems to tell us that when it's all about the money, there's a lot of dirty tricks that can be used to rig the game. I don't think all of this stuff can be made up, so perhaps we've been given a glimpse into the scandals inherent in the system.

*But, what was his motive to kill from the beginning? Who was trying to frame the lawyer and what was their personal motive in doing so? Why would Ryan implicate himself in a murder? He didn't appear to be the killing type; it seemed random. Was it because his mother was a hooker (or dealt her sex for good real estate deals), and he found out, couldn't hurt her, so he takes it out on other hookers?

The story in the book was more complex, thus more interesting. Still, I enjoyed the movie, and especially thought Matthew McC. was a perfect choice for Mickey Haller. If you liked this at all, I highly recommend that you read any of Michael Connelly's books (he's the author of the book that this movie is based on). He's a former journalist who covered crime, so he writes better than most crime novelist. Plus, his books are intelligent and his plots are good.
I did not enjoy the movie at all.  The plot was weak, it was slow to develop and I found myself watching my watch as much as the movie

I loved this movie. Matthew played the perfect lawyer. Trace Adkins played the PERFECT biker. The legal twists played right out of our headlines and have to say couldn't have been written any better.

As a 1L, my husband had to watch the movie by himself after we watched it because I explained to him the reasons the main character couldn't do such and such per the ABA rules of professional conduct.

Great movie. Glad we rented it! Glad we are buying it!

Maybe more of a 3.8 or 3.9 than a 4.0. But - in this day and age - McFestus rounds up. Story - credible. Acting - good.
