William H Macy and John Leguizamo deliver with authority in their brief parts. Ryan Phillipe handles the spoiled young man part with aplomb. Almost as if he has done it before. It's a good solid effort.

This film is about a criminal defense lawyer who practices out of his Lincoln Towncar.  The movie embraces many of the lawyer stereotypes and shows Attorney Mickey Haller (played by McConaughey) wheeling and dealing with his clients to make a buck.  For instance, in several scenes, Haller is shown strong-arming his criminal clients into paying by delaying a trial or making up excuses about the costs of expert witnesses.  Much of what was shown would be unethical and violate the rules of professional responsibility applicable to all attorneys.  But, it makes for good drama.

Without giving too much away, one underlying issue is the impact of the "attorney-client privilege" (a rule that forbids disclosure of confidential information about a client) as it relates to his representation of a present client while learning of information that could exonerate a former client.  Throughout the plot, the audience is given a few twists as Haller investigates the crime and learns what "really" happened.  In my opinion, most are predictable.  But, it is clever how they put it all together in this film.

One of the most interesting parts, in my view, is how Haller gets around attorney-client privilege and cleverly obtains justice in the end.  When you watch it, notice when the detective asks "why did you subpoena me" to come to the trial.  The reason is obvious if you think back to the detective's asking about the client who was in San Quentin and the implication that the detective was familiar with that case.

In the end, it is a great legal drama.

I read the book and it was a very good legal thriller with smart twists. I thought they did a good job in the film, especially when you consider that it was a complex story. I thought McConaughey was perfectly cast as the cagey, street wise lawyer.

Excellent Movie!  I have not seen a movie this amazing in a very long time.  The plot was excellent and you never know what's going to happen next.  Both the client and the lawyer are very conniving and really know how to sell a story. It's an incredible movie to see!

I rarely rate any products anymore, but when they're as outstanding as this one it's important for others to know.  If you're searching for a good movie then this is the one.

I have all but completely stopped watching big studio fiction films, and primarily stick w. documentaries, however the previous high marks and general interest I had after watching the trailer made me roll the $3.99 dice, turns out that was gamble hit the paydirt for a change as this film is a gem in every respect.  It's wonderfully written, directed, and acted...esp. Matthew McCougney who flat out delivered his best performance to date imho.

So anyway, first review...perhaps the last one I ever do, but I believe when a product or service delivers far beyond a customer's expectations, than it's the customer's obligation to spread the good word when avail.

5/5 stars all day long in my book...bravo Lionsgate, your know how to pick the winners and then deliver them better than any other studio, and Ive felt that way for a long time.

I'm not a huge Matthew McConaughey fan, but I did like him in "A Time to Kill." While I haven't read the original novel, my wife and I figured "The Lincoln Lawyer" might be a good midweek flick, and we were right.

McConaughey is Mickey Haller, a defense attorney who seems to do most of his business from the back of an old Lincoln. He's shrewd, wily, and fits right in with those he represents from the shadier side of the streets. As far as he's concerned, he doesn't ever have to feel bad if he loses a case because he knows all his clients are essentially guilty. It seems, though, that his father once warned him about the day he would represent an innocent client. Sure enough, his father's warning proves prescient when Haller ends up being retained by an ultra-wealthy L.A. client, a young man played by Ryan Philippe. This man has been accused of assaulting a hooker in the midst of a transaction, and indeed he was discovered with her blood on his hands, but he swears his innocence.

Haller takes the case. He makes a lot of money from it. But he also uncovers some small lies by his client. What is his client trying to protect? Does it have something to do with a rich mother who suffered abuse of her own? Soon Haller is getting pulled back into an old case and is questioning his own judgment, even while trying to make amends with his ex-wife and his young daughter.

It's pretty obvious early on that something is not right, but the manner in which this unfolds, both in the courtroom and on the streets, makes this a fast-paced and entertaining story. It has some lessons hidden in there about justice and the flaws in the legal system, particularly apropos after the Casey Anthony trial, but it never rises to greatness. There are some sloppy moments that may have worked better in book form. For example, I kept wondering how a Maserati managed to go unnoticed in slum areas, especially when the driver was supposed to be oh, so intelligent.

In the long run, Haller lives up to his own tarnished and questionable character by meting out justice on his own terms. He doesn't prove himself above the law, but he does show that he has a penchant for wanting the truth and wanting justice at all costs, if it means protecting the truly innocent. It leads to some interesting ethical discussions without ever taking itself too seriously in the process.

I just saw this movie and I can't say enough good thing about it.  The acting was superb and it there wasn't a minute where you weren't happy with it.  Matthew McConaughey has proven once again he's a fantastic actor, and the supporting cast was wonderful.  If you can, by all means see this movie.

This left me feeling that this was film-made-by-committee: In some cases the plot has twists and gimmicks that were both intelligent and demonstrative of some of the slight-of-hand that goes on within and without the justice system. That was from the book. Unfortunately, the rest of the writing is like a juvenile living in mom's basement. Matthew McCanoughy is very good as the slick, unconventional attorney, but when you have him approaching a holding cell to talk to someone who's just been arrested surrounded by other prisoners you know the screenwriting is done by someone who's never been near a jail in his life. Similar embarrassing demonstrations of ignorance mar any drama that the courtroom scenes could have/should have had. Absurd give and take from the witness stand and complete lack of understanding concerning what a lawyer would have objected to mingle what is actually a pretty good plot twist. Stereotypical cops, etc. snarl at defence lawyers and ex-wife Asst DAs trample crime scenes at will, as you imagine a teenager directing this nonsense for a high-school film class. Like a boxing movie made by someone who's never been to a boxing-match.

The Movie
What we have here is a nice thriller about a lawyer named Mickey Haller (Matthew McConaughey) taking a case that he will soon find out details and clues as to what he really has got himself involved in. Without giving anything away, the case he gets involved in is about a 32 year old male named Louis Roulet (played by Ryan Philippe) accused of beating up a prostitute. What Haller finds out throughout the case is clues about other cases he has took and all of this leads to frustration considering he finds out he is sort of stuck between a rock and a hard place (you will see why when you watch). The story does take time to evolve. Actually, things go quite slowly for the first 40 minutes or so and then things get going after that. There is a slow build up of suspense throughout, but for what its worth, the 2 hour run time does seem a bit longer considering how dragged out parts of the movie were. On the other hand, we have a good supporting cast around McConaughey including Ryan Philippe, Marisa Tomei, William H. Macy, and even our buddy Bryan Cranston from Breaking Bad makes a couple of brief appearances. I thought all the characters did a very good job in this film, however, The Lincoln Lawyer was all too predictable for the most part which made it less enjoyable than I thought it was going to be. Perhaps the end of the movie picked up too quickly and a lot of things happened at once, but overall this movie deserves a 4 rating which in my book is pretty good, but not great.

Video Quality
Depth is very strong and black levels are deep. This is a very detailed and impressive presentation for the most part. The views outside had quite a bit of depth to them. Palm trees, pavement, scenery, you name it, had high amounts of detail. The presentation was also nice and filmic. There were some scenes with some very light banding if I had one nitpick. Otherwise the video quality is pretty awesome.

Audio Quality
This is not going to be your big budget action movie with explosions, but the DTS-HD MA track got the job done. It does contain a 7.1 mix so those of you with a 7.1 setup will surely be pleased. If you are renting the disc it looks like there is only a 5.1 mix which is really stupid if you ask. Lionsgate must have pressed different copies for the rental edition. Anyways, this is primarily a dialogue driven film and it is delivered very well. The surround speakers were used quite well too at times. You could pick up a lot of little things that were going on in and around the court room from time to time. Better yet was the hip hop tunes that would play and the scenes with the motorcycles. The sound stage came alive during these scenes.

The story had potential but wasn't anything that, for the most part, hasn't been done before. Unfortunately it was so disjointed and poorly edited that it lacked continuity and flow. People and objects suddenly appear and disappear off camera with no reason. The flash backs seemed too flash-backy as if the director knew he had to fill some storyline holes. The rent-a-biker-group of stereotypic old codgers and the strange missing pistol prop and the off screen death of an investigator are a few examples of let's-just-stick'em into the story and see what happens mentality. The courtroom scenes also seemed very staged. The acting was too scripted and predictable as was the obvious things-aren't-what-they-seem plot twists. As far as writing it seemed as if the writer just tossed together bits and pieces of books and movies he had seen before and basically just rearranging the pieces.

A pretty decent legal/courtroom drama, and certainly not the worst MM movie either. He plays a slick defense attorney who up until now has defended scumbags as long as he got a nice paycheck. Without giving anything away, he gets introduced to a potential new client, who is extremely wealthy and is falsely accused of assault. He starts to see dollar signs and from there the game is afoot. Great supporting cast in William H Macy, Marisa Tomei and others. A few cliche moments, and sometimes MM comes off a little too full of himself. Is definably is NOT theater release movie to see, that's why got flop in box office...is very slow type of LIFETIME channel court room drama made for TV movie. Nothing special to WOW u to see in theaters & I am glad I didn't!! >But a rental worth!

Plenty of other reviewers have detailed the jist of the script. Just wanted to say I was pleasantly surprised by this movie, even though I knew it had received good reviews.
It is well acted and well paced with an all star cast that almost feels underused. The pacing is solid and there are enough twists to keep viewers occupied while still supplying a reasonable ending.
Not sure if it is an enduring work of art, but definitely a good bucket of popcorn night of entertainment.

I was a little leary of how the movie would be, due to the cast of Charactors.  I was very impressed by the actors and the movie.  It really did follow the book unusually well and I think Matt did a nice job of portraying Mickey. Hats off to the movie!

I loved the Mickey Haller series by Michael Connelly and was really excited when the movie adaptation of this one was announced.

I was really pleased with the way the movie turned out. While certain elements and events were left out due to time constraints, as with any film, it held very close to the original story line.

I would recommend this to anyone looking for a solid crime fiction story.

THE LINCOLN LAWYER is a classy, well-written (adapted from Michael Connelly's novel by John Romano), well-directed (Brad Furman) drama that benefits from the presence of a well chosen, first class cast. This is one of the stronger movies of the year, the kind of film that reminds us of the art of cinema.

Mike Haller (Matthew McConaughey in a brilliant performance) is a money hungry smarmy defense lawyer whose brilliant mind is bent toward representing sleazy types who pay well.  He works out of his Lincoln automobile driven by his trusted ally Earl (Laurence Mason), lives in a dumpy apartment, works with a shoddy appearing detective Frank (William H Macy), and spars with the beautiful fellow lawyer Maggie McPherson (Marisa Tomei) with whom he has a daughter and an on again off again relationship. One of his fellow workers Val Valenzuela (John Leguizamo) tips Mike on a case of  wealthy realtor Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe) who is accused of beating a prostitute: the case smells of lots of money so Mike of course takes it on - along with Louis, wealthy mother Mary Windsor (Frances Fisher) and the family lawyer Cecil Dobbs (Bob Gunton).  Mike's investigation turns up evidence that suggests his client is not the 'presumed innocent' he appears and there are connections between this case and an old case Mike handled - Jesus Martinez (Michael Peña) - and Mike's usual 'go for the money' attitude takes a turn toward actually seeking justice in the courtroom. A shady dealing lawyer does actually have a conscience and finds a way to prove the truth will out.

There are many cameo roles worthy of mentioning - Josh Lucas plays the prosecuting attorney Ted Minton, Pell James is Mike's girl Friday Lorna, Margarita Levieva is the victim prostitute Reggie Campo, Trace Adkins plays the motorcycle gang head Eddie Vogel, and Shea Whigham inhabits the role of the jail snitch DJ Corliss.  But the major attraction here is Matthew McConaughey's Oscar worthy role: he is magnetic in his transformation from a lawyer you want to loathe to a victor you want to hail.  Marisa Tomei is once again given the opportunity to demonstrate just how fine an actress she is. This is a fast moving, well-scripted film that is simply one of the better moves to come out in a while.  Highly recommended.  Grady Harp, July 11

Finally a new thriller with great careful screenwriting behind it!
After all the "same old, same old...." lately - definitely worth buying.
Great film, great actors.

The Lincoln Lawyer is one of my all time favorite books.  I was pleasantly surprised that the movie so closely resembled the book.  The characters and plot were on point.  I highly recommend this movie (and book!).

I rented this today...I thought it was fantastic!
Matt McConoughey, though I've always admired him, has been in

But this one kind brings his old spark & appeal back.
He turns in an exemplary performance as a lawyer who works out
of the back of his chauffeur-driven Lincoln Town Car, and basically,
for the most part,  has it all down...
That is until he runs into a maniacal, deviantly evil, young rich

have I seen him play such a despicable character with such vicious zeal!

This is a great psychological thriller and has a few surprising twists that will have you saying "OOPS!"
The supporting cast: William H. Macy, John Leguizamo, Marisa Tomei, and others...all do a great job as well.
I will definitely be buying this DVD tomorrow for sure!  Don't miss...

The Lincoln Lawyer is the best Courtroom thriller to come out in years.
The cast is amazing giving Mathew McConaughey his best role since A Time To Kill as Mick Haller the slick, street smart resourceful Defense Attorney who develops a conscience on his journey through this film.
There are just enough twists and turns and nothing that's so absurd that you don't believe it.
I thought it was first rate entertainment and something I could watch over and over.

Matthew McC does a very good job as the lead, the best since he played the religious leader in CONTACT. He is a defense attorney, more likely to be defending Hell's Angels than the hoi polloi.  All that changes though when he gets the scion of a Los Angeles real estate family.  This good looking defendant is played by Ryan Phillipe who is fast becoming a pro at playing creeps. He does a good job but I hope he gets another kind of role soon.

My problem with this film is with the women and specifically the mother of the defendant, played by Frances Fisher. Fisher does a fine job.  However, I read the book years ago and I seem to remember that the mother's role is a lot more complex than the way it is presented in the movie. In fact, the mother's role in the book is a doozy.  So I did not like losing that aspect.

I'm not sure how many more of these ex wife type of roles Marisa Tomei can play.  I think she may be reaching the end of the line with these roles and needs to start looking at more mature parts.

Essentially in this film we have a client, Phillipe, taking over the case by taking one step after another to back his attorney into a corner. Worse yet, the lawyer has a small daughter and has to worry about his client using his daughter's safety to control him.

If I had to choose between reading the book and watching the movie, it would be no contest.  I'd pick the book.  However, if you have no intention of reading the book, the movie is well worth watching and Matthew McC does an excellent job as the lead.

Judge David Johnson, DVD Verdict -- "You know what The Lincoln Lawyer feels like? Old school. I have a difficult time putting my finger on why I feel that way, but it just seems we don't get a lot of movies like these out of the studios these days. There are no visual effects, no bombast, no 3D gimmicks. It's just an actor and a story cleverly told. Credit to McConaughey for bringing this guy to life. He really is electric here, further bolstering his impressive portfolio of attorney roles; he's got that way of being slick and in command and approachable without coming across as a douchebag--vital ingredients to pulling the Haller character off. And though we may be deprived of a neck-twisting Primal Fear-like twist, the thrills are still potent and the payoff is rewarding. Extras are headlined by three HD featurettes: an overall making-of documentary, a tour of LA with Michael Connelly, an interview with McConaughey conducted by Connelly, and a handful of deleted scenes. The 2.35:1, 1080p transfer is a great piece of visual fidelity, and we get a 7.1 DTS-HD audio mix! I thought those were extinct."

Limitless and Source Code are the two best films I've seen this year. The latter being better. Anyway, talking about The Lincoln Lawyer,  I think the film is utterly intriguing. It also has many layers, the central character is interesting and reasonably likable. The court room drama was fascinating, the acting is tight and the direction keeps you interested. The film doesn't hold back at any stage. A very good performance and it's good to see MM do a good job because he's not my favourite actor usually. Ryan Philippe isn't the best brat and the casting on him could have been different but I don't want to give anything away so sorry. Fans of court room dramas have to watch it.

Matthew McConaughey is a talented actor who has spent the last ten years making forgettable romantic-comedies that stunt his ability to show his range. While The Lincoln Lawyer does not have him stepping into Oscar-worthy territory, it's a role that renews faith in his ability as an actor. Additionally, it's a solid film with a tremendous supporting cast and confident direction from relative newcomer Brad Furman (whose IMDB picture, with his Good Charlotte T-shirt and sideways hat, would not lead you to believe he was capable of making a coherent film).

McConaughey plays Mick Haller, a smooth-talking Los Angeles defense attorney who operates out of the backseat of his Lincoln Town Car, defending garden-variety criminals who can pay the right price. Mick is very good at his job and clearly fond of the luxuries it affords. When his driver, Earl, asks him if he can keep the job after Mick gets his license back, Mick replies "I got my license back three months ago, Earl." Out of the blue, a bail bondsman named Val (John Leguizamo) approaches Mick with an offer to defend a high-profile client; Louis Roulet (Ryan Phillippe), the son of a wealthy real estate mogul, has been accused of brutally assaulting a prostitute. Louis vehemently professes his innocence and, although he is suspicious, Mick takes the job. Along with Frank Levin (William H. Macy), his investigator, Mick begins analyzing the evidence to build his case and finds discrepancies that only make his suspicions stronger...

The Lincoln Lawyer starts with a strong script, no doubt adapted from a strong book. I am not familiar with the author of the novel, Michael Connelly, but the last film adapted from one of his books was the 2002 Clint Eastwood thriller Blood Work, which was well-received. Two solid films out of two ain't bad; I think it's a safe bet that he's got talent. The script follows the formula of including a twist at every opportunity and this twisty plot keeps the film surprising and interesting. There are elements that require you to suspend your disbelief a bit (nothing too extraordinary, just too convenient) and it does get contrived at times, but it's much smarter and fun than the average Hollywood legal thriller. There are really two types of films here, the first hour being a mystery while the second being a legal thriller. I was a bit taken aback when they spill the beans only an hour in, but found the courtroom drama just as engrossing as what came before it. The mystery element is effectively intriguing, while the courtroom stuff is well-played, with intensity and snappy dialogue.

It's been a long time since McConaughey was in such fine form. This is a role with real bite and he reminds us that he's a movie star with genuine acting ability. Mick Haller is a suave, charismatic, arrogant, crafty, and manipulative character that McConaughey really sinks his teeth into. As an actor, he naturally exudes charisma and he takes to this character in the same natural way a Jazz musician takes to their instrument. Marissa Tomei as the L.A. prosecutor, and Mick's ex-wife, has a natural chemistry with McConaughey and a likeability and natural warmth that brightens up a film just by having her walk on-screen. Macy doesn't have much screen-time, but has the unique ability as an actor to bring a distinct quirkiness to his role and effectively steal all of his scenes. As the comic relief of sorts, he does just that here. The stunning supporting cast is not short on big names and big talent, consisting of Josh Lucas, Frances Fisher, Michael Pea, Bryan Cranston, and Trace Adkins (!?).

The Lincoln Lawyer is consistently entertaining and suspenseful while it moves at a brisk, clever pace. It has structural similarities to recent films (one that comes immediately to mind is 2007's Fracture), but what it lacks in freshness it makes up for in execution. This is not a film that tries to reinvent the wheel, but merely keep its audience entertained while they watch the wheel spin. It's well-acted and addictive. It's nice to see a film that that aspires only to entertain, but doesn't disregard intelligence completely in doing so. It's not a great film, but it's great entertainment.

GRADE: B

I thought the movie was really good.  Also it was easy to understand,
not complicated and muddled like other movies.  The plot was well developed
and showed how even a married couple of lawyers can disagree fundamentally
on how the law should be applied and upon whom.  That way it was really
great.  The only flaw in the movie was when the criminal's mother is shown
also as a person willing to defend her son by doing criminal acts.  I thought
that was a bit far fetched that a rich upper class lady would be ready to get
into these kinds of activities herself.  That stretched the plot a bit too far.
And could have been handled differently.  The main actor played by Mathew
McCaunaghey was brilliantly acted and handled.  Which shows Mathews ability
to handle drama as well as romance movies.

I am not sure why, but I got the impression that only people in specific professions/fields (e.g. Law)would appreciate such a movie. It is too detailed and complicated that won't be appreciated by everyone. I tried to pay as much attention as possible to the story's details however still got lost and didn't get all of it.

I know this is a good movie, however not for everyone.

Brad Furman's "The Lincoln Lawyer" is a slick, fast-moving, outstandingly entertaining legal thriller about a defense attorney burdened with the client from Hell. Mickey Haller (Matthew McConaughey)--known as "The Lincoln Lawyer" because his office is the back seat of his chauffeured Lincoln Town Car--is an arrogant hotshot who prides himself on being able to play the legal system like Jimi Hendrix played his guitar. After several plot twists and turns, however, Mickey suddenly finds the system playing him. He's even being framed to look like the perpetrator of capital crimes, and because of attorney-client privilege he faces disbarment--or worse--if he tells what he knows.

To say anything more about the plot of "The Lincoln Lawyer" would be a capital crime in itself. Let's just say that the movie keeps you on the edge of your seat literally to the last minute, and that even the savviest thriller fan won't guess all the surprises Furman has in store. Matthew McConaughey hasn't been this good since he played another, very different lawyer in "A Time to Kill," and he is matched by an impeccable supporting cast including Marisa Tomei as his prosecutor ex-wife, Ryan Philippe as a rich kid accused of rape, Frances Fisher as Philippe's imperious mother, William H. Macy as a scruffy P.I. and John Leguizamo as a sleazy bail bondsman. Airtight and engrossing, "The Lincoln Lawyer" is pretty much flawless for what it is.

It is terrific, well acted. If, you like Michael Connelly, you will be so happy that they followed the book very closely. I have not talked with anyone who felt that they were unsatisfied, That says alot to me. I hope that they do more of Michael Connelly books. Mathew McConahy did a wonderful job with the character and the others were great too. I always thought of Mathew as a decent actor but I think that this is his real forte and shows that he is not just a light comedy actor.

WARNING: CONTAINS MIDPOINT PLOT TWIST
Matthew McConaughey plays Mike Haller, a smooth LA high priced lawyer who defends scumbags. He is proud of how he gets off criminals and uses unethical means to do so. However, he sobs like a baby when he finds out he put an innocent man in jail. The local DAs loathe him.

A party girl is beat up and accuses a rich pretty boy (Ryan Phillippe), son of a real estate agent. He claims he was set up and there is evidence to indicate he was set up. However things are not quite right as the our lawyer finds out. Upon investigation he discovers that his client not only beat up the girl, but had done this once before during which the girl was killed except Mike Haller's former Hispanic defendant had taken the rap! Rather than walk away from a big money case, Haller must try to figure out a way to get an innocent Hispanic man out of prison, while presenting a case to make the real killer walk. Marisa Tomei plays the ex-wife and a prosecuter in this film and finally has gotten a role where she keeps her clothes on. William H. Macey has grown his hair out to play a private detective.

Good courtroom drama as well as an intriguing tale as things keep moving and twisting.

I read the book first and then went to see the movie. I think the book was better but the movie was real good. They changed a few things in the movie but was still one of the best I have seen in a while. I enjoyed the twist and turns of it all. I like not knowing till the end "who done it".I sure want to buy the Movie!!

This film is entertaining and well-acted, but in the end I give a mere 3 stars, because it is so unreal in certain important ways.

The Story:
Matthew McConaughey plays a street-wise, prison-wise lawyer (Mickey Haller) who works the system to make a living.  In some ways he's a sleazy guy, representing biker gangs, bribing clerks for info etc, but he's also got a kind heart for his daughter, his ex and his friend Frank (Bill Macy, a private investigator).  I think it's good role for McConaughey, and like a lot of other Hollywood "pretty boys" (e.g. Tom Cruise, Leonardo DiCaprio) his acting gets better as he ages and plays more serious parts.  If you'd ever gotten accused of a crime, his Mickey Haller character would be the guy you'd hire to battle the system!

Haller comes upon a case of a snobby rich young man (Ryan Phillippe) who is accused of a nasty assault on a prostitute, and takes over the case from the family's clueless "blue-blood" lawyer.  Then the story gets intriguing, as you wonder if the rich kid is "playing" Haller.  Then you realize that he is, big time, especially when Macy gets killed, and Haller seems like he's in a deep hole that's impossible to get out of.  It's when he's in this impossible-seeming situation that McConaughey's acting skills come out.  Is he a cool lawyer with the whole world at his feet, or a lonely, angry, divorced drunk who is barely clinging on without losing it?  It's this time of desparation & suffering that gives the movie a little more depth than your typical formulaic film noir.

All Haller has to do is lose the case and the rich snob will be jailed for a long, long time.  But he's set on winning the case for his client and simultaneously getting his client booked for murder. How he does this is a little too slick for me to believe, but I admit it's good escapism.  Also, as many viewers say, the movie has well acted characters.

So WHAT'S WRONG with this movie (SPOILER ALERT BELOW!)?  It took me a while of contemplation to figure this out.  What's wrong with its message? Why doesn't it resonate with me?  It's because it is a total warping of reality.  This movie, while it PURPORTS to be realistic, is total BS reality-wise.  A sleazy defense lawyer who is amoral and works the system for money, is the hero?  A white, handsome, upper-class, Ferrari-driving real-estate salesman and his well-dressed successful Mother are evil Bad Guys, like the Joker and the Riddler?  Biker gangs are other heros who are on the side of the hero?  Of course, we HAVE TO BE PC.  SO ... can't have Blacks or Hispanics, who are 95% of the gang population in LA, be the criminals!  No!  The gang-looking latino who was put in jail for murder, was framed!  He even says "My Mom is going to die when she knows I'm going to jail!"  He says it so well, you think you're going to cry!  Forget about all those other gangbangers who aren't innocent (like the guys who beat the Giants fan into a coma), this movie tells you that you just can't generalize!

So the movie (& I assume the book) depicts a flipped reality in which the population that is probably responsible for <1% of the violent crime in the US (rich, white, USC-educated real-estate selling golfers, AND their mothers) are the evil-doers.  And everyone else in the non-upper-class world: prostitutes, ex-hippies, minorities, bikers, sleaze-bags, are just fine ... i.e. they're GOOD PEOPLE.  Who we should really hate are those rich golfing bastards, not only because we're jealous of their money, and they're not taxed enough of course, but they are evil serial killers to boot and guarded by their homicidal 65 year-old Armani-clothed mothers.

In other words, what passes for a thriller on the surface is also very manipulative class warfare and PC propaganda.  But I guess it's worth a few bucks for some temporary escapism.

The film critics I've read have done an unusually good job discussing The Lincoln Lawyer, as I saw it.  I will just hit the main points about the movie, pro and con, that made an impression on me.  Overall, I thought the movie was well-acted, well-produced, and entertaining, even if limited by what might be called a good TV-caliber screenplay.

The movie drew me in at the very start when the Lincoln town car of the title and its driver turned out not to be the phony Hollywood glitz I had expected but a seedy image that fit the movie perfectly.  (One amateur review's complaint that the car somehow failed to serve its purpose simply because the title character drove around in other vehicles at various points is silly.)  The well-acted characters and unusually dingy L.A. settings generally felt authentic, as far as they went.  Matthew McConaughey fit naturally, smoothly, and effectively into the lead character of Mick Haller.  Haller is a slick, shady L.A. criminal defense lawyer who gets results for his low-life clients, even if things do not always turn out for the best.  Haller runs into serious problems, suffers blows from them, does not act always and mindlessly cocky (unlike the annoying, one-note young prosecutor-on-the-make in the movie Fracture), yet draws on enough strength, ingenuity, and resourcefulness that his confidence rarely fails him.  This made him fun to watch.  Sometimes, he stepped over the line, but not so far as to throw believability to the winds.  The story was basically interesting and tied up fairly neatly.  In fact, it is quite an accomplishment to make a mystery thriller that was generally this entertaining and satisfying without going completely over the top, the way so many of these kind of movies do (such as The Firm, Final Analysis, Just Cause, Guilty as Sin, General's Daughter, and the Ashley Judd films Double Jeopardy and High Crimes).  Lincoln Lawyer was refreshingly free of exploitative, sensational scenes used to gin up cheap shock value, horror, suspense, or titillation.

At the same time, I have to agree with the critics that the movie's story and characters do seem familiar.  Although workmanlike, including the courtroom scenes, well-handled by McConaughey, the movie lacked the sparks of imagination, originality, intricacy, and electricity that can sometimes come from films like this.  It did not really hit the high notes that make watching not just enjoyable but exciting.  The writing, while good, seemed more like a script for a high-quality TV show than theatrical film.  And some of the supporting characters, especially Haller's ex-wife and the bail bondsman, were badly under-developed and pasted on, wasting talented actors in nothing or contrived roles.  Haller's interactions with his ex-wife were not convincing.  Similarly unconvincing was the degree to which he felt a crisis of conscience about the way he represented a past client in light of newly discovered information from representing his current, rich-boy client, accused of trying to beat to death a woman he met at a bar.  Haller had more practical and selfish reasons for resolving the current case the way he did, without delving so deeply into soul-searching and noble motives, which seemed ill-suited to the rest of the movie.

This legal thriller is a refreshing break from all of the mindless, style-over-substance 3D fare Hollywood is churning out lately. It's a throwback to the days of classic courtroom dramas and police procedurals, with enough interesting twists and turns to keep eyeballs glued to the screen. Matthew McConaughey is superbly cast as the smooth operator lawyer. The rest of the casting is also exceptional, down to some of the bit parts like the bail bondsman, the jailhouse snitch, the biker, and the busted hooker. (I especially appreciated William H. Macy as the private investigator; I do wish that Marisa Tomei had a meatier role that allowed her to shine as she did in "My Cousin Vinny.") Michael Connelly is one of the best current authors in the hard-boiled police procedural genre, and the adaptation stays pretty true to his spirit. As someone who works in the criminal justice system, I appreciated the realism. Money, connections, backroom wheeling and dealing, and simple twists of fate often trump justice. Just four stars because although it was solid and great fun to watch, it lacked a profound message or deep impact that would make it  memorable. You certainly won't regret watching it.

CAUTION: If you have not seen this movie, do not watch the trailer. It spoils the plot.

Saw this movie over the weekend.  I must say I was a little afraid that it would be a let down after reading the book, so many times the book doesn't translate well into a movie. Not in this case, besides a few changes that were made, nothing major, the story/movie was spot on. Loved the twist at the end, and how every actor played their part to perfection. I can only hope that they bring back Mickey for a follow up movie sometime down the road. For the readers out there, give this series a try, you want be disappointed.

"The Lincoln Lawyer" with more twists and turns than a corkscrew reminded me of those classic L.A. crime thrillers like "Chinatown," and the hardboiled school of Dashiell Hammett, Raymond Chandler, and James M. Cain. Mickey Haller is a shrewd lawyer who manipulates the law, but can't stand it when he gets set-up and framed. In this one there are multiple set-ups. It is very cleverly woven together. The acting is serviceable and effective, but not superb. It is filmed very neatly with a fast pace that adds to the suspense. It is partly courtroom histrionics, but much of the action takes place outside the courtroom.
 Mickey is played by Matthew McConaughey, and he is well-cast for the part as is Ryan Phillippe, his client who is accused of an assault upon a woman. Mickey is a scammer who even scams the stuffy family attorney with a videotaping scheme.
 At the beginning everything happens at a breakneck speed, and it is difficult to hear the rapid conversation. It settles down, and we catch our breath. Phillippe plays spoiled and wealthy Louis Roulet who fervently pleads his innocence. Haller has been dealing with the lower echelons of the accused, and he needs a financial break. He's represented a member of a biker gang, a mob that shows up regularly in the movie and comes in handy. Other unsavory clients and cases have been Haller's stock and trade. He gets chauffered around in a Lincoln limo by a man who owes Mickey money for handling his drug case.
Get ready for layers of plot intrigue, ploys and mazes within mazes. Never try to scam a scammer, because he's probably going to catch on. I got pulled into this narrative, and the time flew by.
Author Michael Connelly has consistently turned out the best American crime novels of anyone out there. His detective Harry Bosch is legendary. Mickey Haller is a good addition to the Connelly cast. I can see a sequel on the horizon because there are several Haller books in my library.

How far would you go to correct a wrong? After agreeing to take on a case he assumes is an easy win Mickey (McConaughey) soon learns appearances are deceiving. When he finds out the truth and tries to expose it his friends and family are put at risk. I have to admit I actually think McConaughey is very good at playing parts like this. As in "Time To Kill" and "Two For The Money". The smooth man pushed to the edge. Saying almost anything about the movie will give too much info away but I will admit that after being in the "Movie Business" for over 10 years I've seen enough that it's very hard for me to be surprised at a movies ending. The twist at the end of this one had me totally thrown and I love when that happens. I had high expectations for this and it surpassed them all. Watch this movie, you will not regret it. I loved it. As a plus this is a movie that exposes the flaws in the justice system, which will make you mad, and at the same time make you wish more lawyers are like Mickey Haller. I love this movie. I say A+.

Would I watch again? - Absolutely, Im going to buy it!!!

Agatha Christie would be proud of the five-twist ending to THE LINCOLN LAWYER. The film is clearly top-notch and street smart. It's the most efficient, solidly crafted courtroom thriller since PRIMAL FEAR and WITNESS FOR THE PROSECUTION. It has so many twists and turns that it's likely that the popular mystery writer would be giving it her approval.

It also reignites the career of Matthew McConaughey as an actor, not just a charismatic star. He manages to be smoothly appealing despite playing a corrupt lawyer who has no scruples in defending guilty clients as long as they provide the cash flow he demands. It's only after defending RYAN PHILLIPPE from a charge of murder and rape that he realizes he does have a few scruples left. And the plot twists provided by the screenwriter John Romano from the novel by Michael Connelly, are deftly handled for maximum shock effect. Brad Furman keeps the direction tight and forceful.

The cast surrounding McConaughey has been selected with care and all of them offer realistic performances. Marisa Tomei is appealing as his ex-wife who knows his shortcomings but is still attracted to him, and William H. Macy delivers a solid performance as his investigator friend. Ryan Phillippe is excellent as the client whose surface appearance belies the fact that he's as street smart as his sleazy lawyer, and FRANCES FISHER is outstanding in a small but pivotal role as the young man's protective mother.

Not since the days of PRIMAL FEAR and WITNESS FOR THE PROSECUTION has there been a more intelligent script than this one, designed to baffle and blindside the viewer in the course of unraveling some startling surprises.

By all means, highly recommended for fans of this genre.
